newsitem.title: USA: INTERVIEW - Wackenhut in talks to buy 2 firms.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - Wackenhut in talks to buy 2 firms.

text.p: Wackenhut Corp is in talks to buy two Florida-based employee leasing companies with combined 1996 revenue of about $60 million, Wackenhut president and chief operating officer, Richard Wackenhut, said.

Wackenhut, in an interview with Reuters, declined to identify the two, privately owned companies. He said Wackenhut -- a professional human resources management company best known for security services -- was currently in due diligence with one of the Florida companies and talks with the other company were still in the "embryonic stages."
He said Wackenhut could announce one of the acquisitions by May.

The company would pay for the acquisitions with cash and stock and also with new debt, Wackenhut said, adding that it would use its non-voting, Class B stock in any potential deals. The company now has about $6 million in debt, he said.
The acquisitions would contribute about 3,000 -- or some two-thirds -- the 5,000 employees Wackenhut expects to add to its fledgling employee leasing business in 1997.

The company launched the business a month ago and has about 700 employees under contract. It leases the employees to other companies, which enables those companies to cut payroll, administration and other expenses, Richard Wackenhut said.
Wackenhut also said the company -- started by his father in the mid 1950s -- should grow its revenue by $100 million for 1997, bringing total revenue past the $1 billion mark.
He made no earnings projections for the year, saying only that the company expects to grow its net by 20 percent.
He said the company's 55 percent-owned company, Wackenhut Corrections expects to boost its revenue to $200 million for 1997 from about $140 million in 1996.

Wackenhut also said acquisitions for the year might come from the company's food services operations, although declined to be more specific. The company plans to spinoff the operations -- which constitute about eight percent of total Wackenhut revenue -- possibly in 1998, he said.
Wackenhut's stock closed Wednesday at 17-1/4, up 1/4.
The company announced earlier Wednesday that it earned $0.22 per share for its fourth quarter, compared with $0.16 for the year-ago period.
For the year it said it earned $0.66 per share, compared with $0.60 in 1995.
